intro: Gilia tenuituba f. macrosiphon, commonly known as the narrowleaf gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant typically blooms in summer, producing vibrant purple or blue flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats. The foliage consists of narrow, linear leaves that are arranged oppositely along the stems.
